Mu2BxaMBrck8w2DvyYXKgg.text: The chicken rice is very good, maybe comparable to Tian Tian. We had 1.5 chicken, a fishhead claypot, tofu claypot, pork chop, kangkong, sweet potato leaves. Very satisfied group of 13 people.The portion is decent, the service is quick. The servers is the usual coffeeshop standards but they serve good food at great value.

iRD15X3YpHKX99QZ7F7Ryg.text: An excellent meal! A Singapore friend suggested that we eat here. There is no air conditioning (a few ceiling fans around the large seating area) and they do not accept credit cards. It appeared that we were the only Americans in the restaurant at the time. The chicken and rice was outstanding! We ordered a whole chicken, half boiled and half roasted. Both types of chicken were moist and tasty. The rice was also delicious. We also shared a pork chop which was outstanding. The restaurant is a short walk from many hotels in the area. The prices were very reasonable.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Half boiled & half roasted chicken and rice
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Stepping back in time

ojPocrHPKit63JuoCpqKZw.text: I prefer the chicken rice here when in this area, maybe because it serves roast chicken. The pricing (I think $4 for individual serve) is similar to those at food court but the portion is way bigger as it comes in 2 layers of meat on a plate. You get a miserly amount in food court. The chicken is flavorful and the breast meat is not that dry. The chili sauce is quite spicy so go sparingly on it. The grated ginger sauce is just ginger with no scallions or chopped green onions in it. The service is typical of coffee shop - efficient and brusque. There are other dishes available but I have yet to try any.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Aloe Vera and luo Han guo drink.
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Roast or white chicken or both? Two layers of meat for each plate. $11.20 for 2 plates and 2 drinks.

HzZA27_rO1OBBVJTCOAQ1A.text: This restaurant is the best hainam place in.bugis. since i want to visit bugis, so i looked for a nearby place to eat local food. And they served best hainam chicken. I just haven't got a chance to taste the pork, i bet it taste great also..

SXQUg3iRBVJhdjHAbZ2vug.text: I've been here several times over the past decade yet I've never had the Hainanese pork chop. Big mistake! It was so tasty we ordered a second serving! Besides the pork chop, we also had the chicken rice, eggplant with salted fish, kailan and hei zhor (minced meat roll). They were good but not outstanding to specially return. The bill came to about $50 for 4 persons.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

8vDVooEf-ccs0VnmV58OJg.text: Situated along the shop houses of Purvis Street, Chin Chin Eating House facade is one of the most humble looking among her neighbouring modern eateries. Astounded by the crowd during dinner time, we walked into the eating place and tried to grab a seat. Lo and behold, there was a table for 2, just nice!Besides having good pork chop, they do sell Haianese Chicken Rice, Claypot Mutton Soup which I believe had been drawing the hordes thus its full house on a saturday night. The restaurant interior was simple and decent with hanging ceiling fans at each sector above. Chinese Lanterns were seen hanging from the florescent lights too.Haianese Pork Chop, being one of its Must Try on their Menu had been awarded for its Best Food for 2011 and 2012.It's not quite frequent we come across this dish on the menu moreover it had won the award. Having prepared similar dish, I would say that it was quite good but not really what I would expected. The dish was served with few pototoes wedes and boiled green peas with a bowl of tomato gravy.The piece of lean meat was fried to golden brown with crumbs coated evenly at its exterior. It was cut into smaller portions equally and was served.Braised Ee Mee tasted better than average. It's black braised sauce was aromatic and noodles was generously drenched, a little more would have the gravy overflowed.Having tried only 2 dishes, I would definitely be back for more when chance come!Total amount spend for 2 with drinks: $30

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

qc7KnzAn2OBGc1UrWKlrUQ.text: This seems like a popular place and got good ratings so we brought our visitor here.  The chicken is pretty good, but I also can't say it's a lot better than any of the other equally well known chicken rice places.  Personally I prefer the chicken rice at Tian Tian or Boon Tong Kee but I have not tried the roast chicken though so perhaps that's better?One of their signature dishes is the Hainanese pork chop but I found that to be just ok - the meat is a bit dry and I prefer it to be thicker and more succulent.  Other dishes like stir fried kangkung are ok but nothing special.  Prices are pretty cheap so definitely a good value for money.

0o8zdxlK8n05XqUVOADhWQ.text: Very Very good...I love the garlic chili and crushed ginger on the table. Great food...but not cheap.

Nvbk4k0yJD_oNdUWpaIlTg.text: Came all the way for the chicken rice and mutton soup but the mutton soup was already sold out. First time here and it was really one of the best chicken rice I've had. Would definitely come back!!

JHXuVVHSXsLaJuhQXvpIWw.text: The Hainanese chicken rice is deliciuous, which is better than Yet Con (tho my fav is still Tian Tian :P) Half a chicken is good for 2 person. And each of us ordered a dish of chicken oil rice, which is lovely too. However, the Hainanese veggie is so-so, too watery and salty.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

GOuOg2bl0l0MmVXfQc93YQ.text: Among all the stalls that I have tried, this is the best due to the soft fragrant rice, the chilli and the tenderness of chicken.  The portion is big. Generous spring onions on the chicken soup too. S$4 for a set.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

piYiFiSd4DQ6lg88jUdh6g.text: Best items were the chicken rice and the hainanese pork chop (like Japanese pork cutlet). Other items I did not care for. Make your own dipping sauce before meal begins. Bring your own napkins and wet wipes as there are none at this economy restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken plated
Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chickens in window

wLECs0TyyNQOH0baW2sZWA.text: Chin Chin Eating House has been my go-to place for fast and convenient zichar and chicken rice since young. This place is what a zichar place is like - hot, crowded, noisy and big tables with lazy susans in their middle. A typical local eatery with no airs about it and where people can just come and have a good meal at any time of the day.Other than the chicken rice and chicken that are must-trys, I will recommend their pork chop and chap chye. If you are a tourist and want to try local food, get out of Raffles Hotel and walk one street down to Chin Chin Eating House!

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

2bj81zgJv_tRhlIMI-v_gQ.text: Tried this place several months ago and made a point of returning because it was so good. Not sure why chicken rice isn't on their (rather extensive) menu, but that's the dish to get. Perfect tenderness and flavor, a great broth to accompany it, and the chili/ginger are so good that I get an upset stomach every time (in the best way possible - watch your spice levels, people). Right up there with Tian Tian at Maxwell.

photos.caption: Photo of Chin Chin Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken rice (with spice!)

XDCGyolXyXut5Rer7iWu5w.text: OK food. Terrible service. No one could speak Engilsh, the wait staff ignored people they thought couldn't speak Chinese. Never going again.

0rudBOslTwd1n-vd8clLgw.text: Purvis street used to house many European families which had Hainanese chefs working for them so I'm not surprised that it is a known haunt for the best Hainanese food in town.Get the Hainanese pork chops - sweet ketchup sauce drenching crispy pork cutlet is the ultimate comfort food that reminds one of childhood meals by the grandmother. I even like that crinkle-cut fries are stir-fried into the dish too. Super old school!I've yet to try more Hainanese dishes from here but it is a safe bet if you're looking to go good old traditional!

SbYkkcwfZBPFkf_7juGMKQ.text: Along the stretch of shophouse restaurants at Purvis Street, this stall has old chicken rice seller Yet Con Restaurant to compete with, but Chin Chin Eating House has nothing to worry about. In a traditional local coffee shop setting, Chin Chin Eating House sure looks like it goes way back. Studying in a nearby school, Chin Chin is an eating haunt for my friends and I. The dishes that we regularly order include chicken rice, Hainanese pork chops, Hainanese chap chye and claypot beancurd. The chicken rice has an authentic taste to it, and the chicken is blanched in cold water after cooking, making the skin smooth and the texture of the meat tender. Afterwhich, the chicken is served in a flavorful and aromatic sauce. The Hainanese pork chops here are passable but if you want a better version, try the one at Yet Con just across the street.My favorite dish at Chin Chin has to be the Chap Chye. The vegetables are fresh and crunchy and the sauce is the deal breaker. The sauce has a special oomph to it, which is provided by the dried cuttlefish strips I guess.

y8xsow444AYzZpHWHEFp3w.text: This place came recommended by a friend who lives here in Singapore. Chicken rice was pretty tasty and was only $4. Service was not great which was to be expected. The beer was only 6.30 for a large beer. Overall this place is pretty good.
